title: transitional but more calligraphic than usual
content:
Driving me crazy. I know I've seen it many times, but can't name it.

| Attachment | Size |
| --- | --- |
| [transwhational.jpg](http://web.archive.org/web/20130530021525/http:/typophile.com/files/transwhational.jpg) | 13.28 KB |
author: Brian_

comments.content:
Ellington bold I think, squooshed a little

[http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/linotype/ellington/mt-bold/](http://web.archive.org/web/20130530021525/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/linotype/ellington/mt-bold/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/linotype/ellington/mt-bold/")

Right on Patty. Ellington is one of my favorite fonts, as is the sans companion font - [Strayhorn](http://web.archive.org/web/20130530021525/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/linotype/strayhorn-mt/). The designer, Michael Harvey is a jazz fan -- Billy Strayhorn was Duke Ellington's friend, and arranger on many of his famous pieces.There is also the display face [Braff](http://web.archive.org/web/20130530021525/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/agfa/braff/), named for Ruby Braff, a top cornet & trumpet player who had recorded with Ellington, among many others.

End of typographical jazz lecture. :)

- Mike Yanega

Lectures welcome!  
Thanks to you both.  
Brian
